article-meta.aff: 2Dr Nafiz Korez Sincan Government Hospital of Ministry of Health, Ankara, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Şebnem Kupana Ayva, Department of Pathology, Medical Faculty, Kirikkale University, 71100, Saglık Sok, Kirikkale, Turkey Email: ekupana@yahoo.com

abstract.p: Adenohibernoma of the breast is a very rare tumor composed of brown fat tissue and intermingled glandular tissue. There are only 2 case reports in literature. This study reports the third case of adenohibernoma of the breast, which is not accompanied by breast cancer differing from the previous cases. And, to the best of the authors’ knowledge, this is also the first case of adenohibernoma of the breast that has demonstrated adipophilin expression immunohistochemically.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The presence of brown fat tissue within the breast parenchyma is a rare event. There have been several reports describing mammary lesions composed of hibernomatous elements.1-8 These lesions are a heterogenous group of true neoplasms, including adenohibernoma,1,2 hibernoma,3-7 and hamartoma of the breast.8 Adenohibernoma is rare tumor composed of glandular elements of breast and brown adipose tissue stroma.1,2 Damiani and Panarelli1 reported the first case of adenohibernoma in 1996 and up to now only 2 patients have been reported.1,2
The third case of adenohibernoma of breast is presented here to discuss the clinical and histopathological features of brown fat tissue lesions of breast.

sec.title: Case
sec.p: A 27-year-old woman underwent excisional biopsy because of a hyperechoic fusiform-shaped nodule in the right breast revealed by ultrasound examination. The clinical history was unremarkable.
Gross pathological examination revealed a soft, well-circumscribed nodule, 2 cm long in its major axis. The cut surface was yellow-tan in color.

Microscopically, the mass lesion consisted of 2 components, one of which included predominantly brown fat tissue and the other had glandulary mammary parenchyma. However, there was less glandulary mammary parenchyma than the brown fat tissue in the lesion. There existed dilated ducts and distorted lobules, which had little or no proliferative epithelial change, in glandulary mammary parenchyma of the lesion (Figures 1A to 1C). Some areas of the lesion exhibited proliferation of ducts without lobules. The periductal stroma was loose. The fat component of the lesion had lobular pattern, including large multivacuolated cells that showed small, centrally located nuclei. There were also mixed univacuolar cells with peripherally placed nuclei (Figure 1D). Some of these cells were stained strongly for S-100 protein (Thermo Fischer Scientific Lab Vision, Ready-to-use, Waltham, MA, USA) immunohistochemically using the standard labeled avidin–biotin peroxidase complex method (Figure 2A). Multivacuolated cells demonstrated from moderate to strong positive immunostaining for adipophilin (Progen, dilution 1/10, Heidelberg, Germany). Univacuolated cells were generally negative for this antibody (Figure 2B). Univacuolated and multivacuolated cells were negative for CD68 (Thermo Fischer Scientific Neomarker’s, Waltham, MA, USA). According to these histopathologic findings, we suggest that this case may be diagnosed as adenohibernoma of breast.

caption.p: (A-C) The lesion is composed of glandular structures that consist of distorted lobules and dilated ducts exhibiting a thin myoepithelial layer and brown fat lobules (hematoxylin and eosin: A, 40×; B, 100×; C, 100×). (D) The brown fat component of the lesion is constituted by multivacuolated fat cells mixed with univacuolated fat cells (hematoxylin and eosin, 200×)
(A) The brown fat cells are strongly positive for S-100 protein (diaminobenzidine, 100×). (B) Multivacuolated brown fat cells are positive for adipophilin (diaminobenzidine, 100×)

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Presence of brown fat tissue within the breast parenchyma is uncommon1-8 (Table 1). Several terms have been used to describe these lesions. First entity is hibernoma describing benign tumor composed of brown adipose tissue, which is found most commonly in hibernating animals. So far, 6 cases have been reported as mammary hibernoma.3-7 In the largest series of hibernomas to date, 2 of 170 cases were located in the breast.4 Second entity is adenohibernoma, which harbors hibernoma containing glands. Up to date, only 2 case reports have been published.1,2 As there are very few cases in the literature, the diagnosis criteria have not adequately identified. Taking into consideration of these data, the lesion, which consists of brown fat tissue and glandulary mammary parenchyma, may be defined as adenohibernoma. Since our case showed hibernoma intermixed with mammary glands, we suggest that this patient may be considered as the third case of adenohibernoma in the literature.

caption.p: Published Mammary Lesions That Have Brown Fat Tissue Component

tr.td: In situ comedo carcinoma associated with Paget’s disease of the nipple
Superior outer quadrant of the left breast/25 mm
Superior outer quadrant of the right breast/45 mm
Inferior inner quadrant of the right breast/18 mm
Superior outer quadrant of the right breast/22 mm
Hormonal substitute therapy for radical hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy
Mammary hamartoma with brown adipose tissue

sec.p: Adenohibernomas may be found as either a painless, firm, a well-circumscribed, solitary tumor during the routine physical and radiological examinations as observed in our patient or seen incidentally in surgical specimens.1,2 Adenohibernoma is a well-circumscribed nodular mass. It has been reported that these tumors are 3 to 10 mm in diameter.1,2 In our case, the mass was 2 cm long in its major axis. Multiple lesions have not been detected synchronously and metachronously in the same or opposite breast. The right breast is affected slightly more often than the left one.

Adenohibernomas are characterized by circumscribed nodules composed of intermingled glands and brown fat lobules. The mixture of normal lobules, dilated ducts, sclerosing adenosis-like changes, and focal apocrine changes may be observed in the glandular component of adenohibernoma. The fat component of these lesions is predominantly constituted by lobules of multivacuolated polygonal adipocytes showing small, centrally located nuclei. Univacuolar cells with peripherally located nuclei are also seen.1,2

Adipophilin is an intracellular membrane protein including the residual membrane proteins of intracytoplasmic lipid vesicles.9 This protein has been identified in various normal cell types, including zona fasiculata cells of the adrenal gland, sertoli and leydig cells, lactating mammary epithelial cells, steatosis, or fatty change hepatocytes in alcoholic liver cirrhosis.10 It has been suggested that adipophilin is helpful in the identification of intracytoplasmic lipids as seen in sebaceous lesions.9 However, it has been found that mature adipocytes of fibrose tissue do not demonstrate immunostaining for adipophilin.10 The interesting finding of our case was that it demonstrated adipophilin-stained multivacuolated cells of brown fat tissue. Univacuolated cells were negative for this antibody. The expression of adipophilin in the adenohibernoma of the breast has not been described previously. The most common immune profile for adenohibernoma is diffuse S-100 protein positivity in brown fat tissue. In addition to adipophilin in our case, immunohistochemical analysis of lesion showed S-100 protein positivity in brown fat tissue.

Despite detailed knowledge about the histopathologic features of adenohibernoma, little is known about its pathogenesis. Damiani and Panarelli1 suggested a hamartomatous origin from remnants of fetal brown adipose tissue or alternatively the possibility of de novo mixed proliferation showing brown fat differentiation in its mesenchymal component for adenohibernomas. Kapucuoglu et al2 proposed that brown fat is not a normal constituent of adult tissue and in this respect adenohibernomas may not be regarded as hamartoma. According to these authors, whether the adenohibernomas are part of the group of fibroadenomas containing brown fat is open to question. They suggested that adenohibernoma could be regarded as a new entity and that it was different from fibroadenoma.2 Garijo et al8 described a case of mammary hamartoma with brown fat tissue. They considered that their lesion was a variant of hamartoma and it could not be termed as adenohibernoma, since it was not a predominantly fatty tumor.8 As a consequence of this knowledge, it was regarded as adenohibernoma because hibernomatous stromal component was more dominant and contained benign glandular component in our case. The question of whether the definition of adenohibernoma includes the possibility of entrapped normal breast parenchyma in a simple hibernoma has been also considered.

Adenohibernoma should be considered histopathologically in the differential diagnosis of mammary hibernoma, mammary hamartoma, fat necrosis, and other tumors composed of granular multilocular cytoplasm. Adenohibernoma is differentiated from hibernoma by intermingled glandular component and brown fat lobules. The distinction of mammary hamartoma from adenohibernoma may be performed by the amount of brown fat tissue. Whereas granular cell tumor and foamy macrophages in fat necrosis have positive CD68, multivacuolated cells in adenohibernoma have negative CD68. In our case, CD68 staining in the cells was not observed. Thus, these diagnoses were ruled out.

Surgical excision is perhaps the appropriate choice in treatment. There are no data about spontaneous regression of these tumors. Adenohibernoma is accepted as benign in nature and no recurrence has been reported after total excision. Two cases of adenohibernoma reported in literature showed coincidental occurrence with breast cancer: one, an 80-year-old woman with in situ comedocarcinoma associated with Paget’s diseases1 and the other, a 57-year-old woman with tubular carcinoma.2 To the best of our knowledge, our case is the first report of this very rare tumor with which the breast carcinoma is not accompanied.

Despite advances in imaging techniques, the diagnosis of adenohibernoma still depends on histopathologic examination. It may be difficult to interpret a tissue core biopsy sample of such a lesion particularly if only glandular component is present.

To conclude, adenohibernoma of breast should be considered in the differential diagnosis of breast masses, especially if accompanying breast cancer is detected. The use of adipophilin antibody may play an important role either alone or in addition to an immunohistochemical panel to confirm the diagnosis of adenohibernoma.
